concepts.title: Shortcut to System Design Mastery
concepts.summary: Three-part syllabus: study real-world blueprints, follow active engineering blogs, and ground yourself in core theory to connect principles to implementations.

sections.name: Scope & Goal
points: Mission: build system design mastery efficiently by pairing universal principles with concrete tech implementations.
Audience: engineers targeting large-scale systems and interviews; focus on mapping concepts to real architectures.

sections.name: Blueprints (Case Studies)
points: Facebook: denormalized feeds; Haystack for immutable photos (fast seeks), TAO for social graph reads, massive memcache optimizations; Erlang for chat concurrency.
Amazon Dynamo: availability-first KV store; eventual consistency with vector clocks and app-level reconciliation.
Google Trinity: GFS (fault-tolerant file system), Bigtable (structured storage at PB scale), MapReduce; differential sync (OT) powering Google Docs.
Twitter: fanout challenges; Snowflake 64-bit time-sortable IDs for ordered writes without a central coordinator.
Other blueprints: Pinterest, LinkedIn, Flickr, Dropbox, WhatsApp highlight specialized solutions to common scale problems.

sections.name: Current Insight (Engineering Blogs)
points: Why: capture v2/v3 evolutions, ops maturity, incident learnings not in papers.
Examples: Netflix (resilience, microservices, A/B), Stripe/Shopify/PayPal (payments integrity), Amazon/eBay (e-commerce scale), GitHub/Slack/Docker/Asana (dev productivity).
Action: maintain a rotation of blogs across domains to see how systems change and fail in practice.

sections.name: Foundational Theory
points: Understanding Distributed Systems: networking stack, messaging, consensus (Paxos/Raft) as bedrock for reliability.
Designing Data-Intensive Applications: storage engines, isolation levels, replication/partitioning; bridges theory to implementation.
The Tech Resume Inside Out: translate architecture knowledge into recruiter-visible impact; career leverage for the technical depth.

sections.name: Synthesis Pattern
points: Map concept → tech: eventual consistency → Dynamo; time-sortable IDs → Snowflake; denormalization → Facebook timeline; immutable blob store → Haystack.
Active learning: connect principle, implementation, trade-offs (availability vs consistency, cost vs latency).
Philosophical prompt: which trade-off compels you more—strict consistency or high availability—when designing at scale?
